content.question: A data scientist had <math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn></math> different sets of data. For each data set the scientist fit a least-squares regression line, then graphed the residuals versus the predicted values for each. Which residual plot indicates that the least-squares regression model was the most appropriate model to fit the data?

choices.label: The figure shows a scatterplot in a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled “Predicted,” and the numbers 95 through 115, in increments of 5, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled “Residual,” and the numbers negative 6 through 1, in increments of 1, are indicated. The data points begin in the lower left portion of the plane, and trend upward and to the right initially. The data points increase in number as the trend reaches a maximum at the point with coordinates 104 comma 1. The data points then trend downward and to the right and decrease in number as the trend approaches the lower right portion of the plane, where it ends. Note that all coordinate values are approximate.

The figure shows a scatterplot in a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled “Predicted,” and the numbers negative 20 through 180, in increments of 40, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled “Residual,” and the numbers negative 2 through 6, in increments of 1, are indicated. The data points begin in the upper left portion of the plane, and trend downward and to the right initially. The data points increase in number, and the band of data points becomes wider as the trend reaches a minimum at the point with coordinates 75 comma negative 2. The data points then trend upward and to the right. The data points decrease in number and the band of data points becomes narrower as the trend approaches the upper right portion of the plane, where it ends. Note that all coordinate values are approximate.

The figure shows a scatterplot in a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled “Predicted,” and the numbers 10 through 60, in increments of 10, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled “Residual,” and the numbers negative 2 through 4, in increments of 1, are indicated. The data points begin at the point with coordinates 8 comma negative 3, and trend upward and to the right. The data points begin to move steeply upward and to the right as they approach the point with coordinates 23 comma 0. From here, the data points move more gradually upward and to the right until they end at the point with coordinates 60 comma 4. The number of data points in the cluster is consistent throughout the trend of data points. Note that all coordinate values are approximate.

The figure shows a scatterplot in a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled “Predicted,” and the numbers 0.7 through 1.4, in increments of 0.1, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled “Residual,” and the numbers negative 1.5 through 2.5, in increments of 0.5, are indicated. The data points are scattered throughout the scatterplot.

The figure shows a scatterplot in a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled “Predicted,” and the numbers 2 through 20, in increments of 2, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled “Residual,” and the numbers negative 3 through 3, in increments of 1, are indicated. The data points begin at the point with coordinates 2 comma negative 3, and trend upward and to the right at an increasing rate. The data points include the point with coordinates 12 comma negative 1, and end at the point with coordinates 20 comma 3. The number of data points in the cluster is consistent throughout the trend of data points. Note that all coordinate values are approximate.

content.answer: The figure shows a scatterplot in a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled “Predicted,” and the numbers 0.7 through 1.4, in increments of 0.1, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled “Residual,” and the numbers negative 1.5 through 2.5, in increments of 0.5, are indicated. The data points are scattered throughout the scatterplot.

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Interpret statistical calculations and findings to assign meaning or assess a claim.
